response.answer_text: They sure can! Sodium, potassium and calcium ions are responsible for the generation and transportation of electrical current (so-called signals) in our bodies. Also neurons “talk” to each other via ionic electrical current. Ions are also the reason why most of the people believe “water” is electrically conductive. Without the foreign ions in “common water” that would not be the case. (And no, the ions provided by autoprotolysis would not be enough). “Pure” water has an electrical conductivity that is 15000–200000 times lower than tap water and is equally conductive as sand stone or ceramics. In other words, pure water is an electrical isolator according to our definitions of conductivity.

Yes. A current is a bunch of charged particles moving in roughly the same direction. If a field (like an E or a dB/dt) is present and ions can move, a ionic current results. In a plasma both electrons and ions are free to move. There are huge currents in the plasma in Tokamaks. A large portion is ion movement. Ion gun intensity and Proton Therapy does (and here) is measured in nano-, micro-, or milli-amps — which is a measure of the number of ions passing through a plane. The MeV specifies how fast the ions are traveling.
